text:
It may feel like mere days since this year’s Oscars red carpet was being rolled out, but awards season will soon be swinging around again. So now’s the time to catch-up or re-watch the movies that dominated the 2018 nominees lists.

All of the big-hitters below are available to stream on this Christmas, so there’s no excuse not to make the most of the miserable winter weather and settle in for a movie marathon. Dramatic gown optional.

For some fantasy romance… The Shape of Water

20th Century Studios

We’re not going to lie, we weren’t sure what to expect from a film about a mute cleaner who falls in love with a humanoid amphibian. And yes, that really is the storyline. But its uniqueness is what makes it special – even when it comes to the now-infamous bathroom scene. We’ll leave you to work out what goes on there.

The movie, which beat some seriously strong contenders to win Best Picture at the Oscars, is beautifully shot – and we love that Sally Hawkins was nominated for Best Actress for playing a character who communicates through sign language. She stars alongside Octavia Spencer, who’s as brilliant as ever. Expect to become fully immersed (pun intended).

For a thoroughly British drama… Darkest Hour

Universal

In this WWII biopic Gary Oldman plays Winston Churchill, undergoing the most mind-blowing makeover since Charlize Theron’s transformation in Monster. Oldman bagged the Best Actor accolade at the Oscars, BAFTAs and Golden Globes, so it’s fair to say you’ll be blown away by his performance.

There’s also a strong female supporting cast: Lily James portrays the politician’s personal secretary, while Kristin Scott Thomas is fantastic as his loyal wife Clemmie. A great choice to watch with your family over Christmas.

For a gritty drama… Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri

20th Century Studios

This smart, intense, bittersweet story centres around Mildred Hayes (Frances McDormand), who’s dealing with the murder of her teenage daughter. Angry over the lack of progress in the investigation, Mildred rents three billboards, posting messages to the local police chief (Woody Harrelson).

Winning the Golden Globe for Best Picture and the BAFTA for Best Film, you wouldn’t think a drama about a grieving mother could have moments of wry comedy amongst the tragedy, but Three Billboards manages it. Frances McDormand is a total powerhouse (it’s no surprise she won Best Actress at the Oscars, Golden Globes and BAFTAs) and will keep you gripped from start to finish.

For an epic animation… Coco

Walt Disney/Pixar

Inspired by Mexico’s Day of the Dead celebrations, this Disney Pixar gem follows a 12-year-old boy who’s accidentally transported to the Land of the Dead, and needs his great-great-grandfather’s help to get back to world of the living.

It might be aimed at kids, but it’s been making grown adults blub since its release. Praised for its moving storyline and respect for Mexican culture, it cleaned up during awards season, winning Best Animated Film at the Oscars, BAFTAs and Golden Globes.

Even if you haven’t watched it, you probably already know its (Oscar-winning) lead song. Remember Me has been stuck in our heads for months.

For a sun-soaked love story… Call Me By Your Name

Sony Pictures

The movie that put Timothée Chalamet on our radar – Call Me By Your Name is set in 1980s Italy and follows the budding relationship between 17-year-old Elio (Chalamet) and his father's assistant Oliver (Armie Hammer).

Based on the novel by American writer André Aciman, it won Best Adapted Screenplay at the Oscars and BAFTAs. There’s no crazy drama, just a beautiful love story that draws you in. And thanks to its picturesque setting, it’s gorgeous to look at. Don’t blame us if you’re booking flights to Italy by the time the credits roll.
